review: Nina Hoss delivers perhaps the very best and most challenging performance of her career in this gripping film about what it is like to become a stranger to the person you love (and vice versa) - even though the suicide of a certain character comes up as quite unnecessary.

A very moving story of a woman who has been betrayed to the Nazis and returns to her home town to reconcile with her husband despite having a new face. The final scene remains long after the film has ended.

The plot is so nuanced, the characters so keenly observed and realized that it's shocking that the movie is also so economical . . . No moment is wasted as the film builds to what I can only describe as a perfect ending.

It is a shame that most moviegoers will not see this film because it is one of the best films of 2015 and the best acting by either male or female so far this year. Nina Hoss is terrific in this and in the two that I have had the pleasure to watch her in (Barbara and A Most Wanted Man). An interesting story about an interesting woman during post war Berlin. (9-27-15)
A sort of realist The Skin I Live In, beguilingly made and acted and with a breathtaking and simple final shot. Bravo.

As stylish as "The Third Man," another film about the immediate and quite unpleasant aftermath of WWII, "Phoenix" is a character study with a suspenseful mystery in its cold heart. Nelly searches the seedy haunts of Berlin to find her ex-husband, and when she does, boom. Great finale.

a tale of marriage, adversity, betrayal, greed, forgiveness and revelation in the context of a scarred holocaust concentration camp survivor who has to face with the dread that the person she was living for was not who she thought she knew, and as she faces the continual task of pretending to be her former self, she realizes who she wants to, and has to, be.
A thoroughly ludicrous central plot element knocks the otherwise gorgeously acted and thematically compelling Phoenix down several pegs
I guess not all love is true love.
It was OK, not exactly what I would call spellbinding.

this film is no typical "historical drama". at first this is what you are used to facing this topic. but i think it doesnt want to be realistic. its plot is more like a metaphor, a parable for the impossibility to return to the "normal" life jewish and non jewish people had after what happend in the holocaust and the very different implications this has for both sides..expressing this thought the film does perfectly well.
In that final scene alone, Nina Hoss tells a whole story but strips it of all melodrama, so that Nelly, unlike Lene, can move on.
What a brain twister. At first ya think, I don't know? In the end, you are shouting at the screen "no, no, there has to be more". A great flick.
Densely executed and something really different.

Really loved the talent in this - Nina Hoss did a really good job at bringing to life this post-Auschwitz survivor trying to put her life back together and continue on as if nothing happened - or at least to regain some sense of normalcy.The issue I had with the film was the way Hoss's character just kept striving to get her husband to realize she was the one he was training to impersonate... herself. At no point did she throw her hands up in the air like "WHAT THE HELL IS WRONG WITH YOU" - she didn't look significantly different from before after her reconstructive surgery so it seemed very strange to me that he meant so much to her that she wouldn't give up trying to be subtle with him.The other thing I really loved about the film came during the entire third act and ESPECIALLY THE END. What a button. Credits roll and you want to cheer for her character. Definitely worth your frustrations with her character for such a stinging end.

A very good film, but not the great masterpiece that many critics try to make out of it. There's nothing wrong with the film itself, but the premise is very far-fetched and I didn't feel comfortable seeing the Holocaust reduced on a melodramatic conflict. And that's what it is: It's melodrama in its purest form, very well acted and directed, but everything about it feels artificial like a postmodern exercise.

um drama comovente definido nos escombros do p�s-guerra em Berlim.o artif�cio narrativo bem trabalhado choca de frente com o realismo sombrio do roteiro.
The plot may be a little outlandish but the film underplays it effectively, doubling as a powerful metaphor for post-war Germany.

The subtle and richly detailed performances of both Hoss and Zehrfeld, the powerful cinematography, and the devastating culminating scene of "Phoenix" make the film one of the best and most memorable of its genre.

Part Holocaust drama, part noir, part WWII version of Alfred Hitchcock's Vertigo, Christian Petzold's Phoenix is masterful storytelling at its best. Gloriously photographed and excellently acted by Nina Hoss and Ronald Zehrfeld, this is one of the best movies of the year.

The movie as a whole is beautifully paced. Petzold shows an incredible amount of restraint in terms of letting the story unfold in a tense yet quiet manner until it hits what may be one of the best closing moments in a film I've seen in the last ten years. The restraint and economy of how the ending unfolds really blew me away.
Simple and terrifically acted, the slow build up to the final scene pays off big time
Powerful, very well crafted, and exceptionally acted.
A bit slow but if you stick in there till the end, it's worth it.

The plot is so nuanced, the characters so keenly observed and realized that it's shocking that the movie is also so economical . . . No moment is wasted as the film builds to what I can only describe as a perfect ending.

Overhyped and pretentious German thriller that depends on the monumental stupidity of a central character to drive the story forward. Good production value and performance from Nina Hoss, but not anywhere near the classic that it is made out to be. One of the rare instances when Rotten Tomatoes score is completely misleading.
3.5 / 5.0 Too slow a burn...

As stylish as "The Third Man," another film about the immediate and quite unpleasant aftermath of WWII, "Phoenix" is a character study with a suspenseful mystery in its cold heart. Nelly searches the seedy haunts of Berlin to find her ex-husband, and when she does, boom. Great finale.

Intriguing from start to finish, smartly written and remarkably directed. Christian Petzold's "Phoenix" its an extraordinary film. Nina Hoss subtle, powerful performance elevates the material even more.

There are big problems with the premises of this movie, that make it impossible to swallow, unless you lose all respect for the characters. The final scene reveals the ideology the film is interested in pushing, but it just doesn't work!

This well-crafted German film, featuring a unique storyline, is set during the end of WWII. Featuring solid performances and superbly shot, Phoenix contains subtly, intrigue and mystery. The final scene, which brings many of the film's elements together, is both emotional and powerful for the lead character.

The central mystery that drives Phoenix is tense and unbelievably powerful, but what really makes it something incredible is the assessment of perception and identity that comes from the focus on the two main characters. In the aftermath of the second world war, the notion that anyone could return to a country that had committed such an egregious act of genocide at all, let alone rebuild a relationship that once was, seems futile immediately. It doesn't matter how desperate anyone is to get back a semblance of the life that used to exist before the concentration camps; there's no coming back from that. When she arrives, she notices her reflection in shards of glass. She shudders as a train goes by, hauling those awful carts. The identity of the woman and the nation in which she lives has been changed forever, and in order to move on, she must build something entirely new. She can't forget the past, but must look forward anyway.

As proof that the maxim "don't mention the war" has well and truly ceased to apply, the krauts have ripped off Vertigo and still managed to make it about the holocaust. Reasonably well put together (especially when it comes to the central performance by Nina Hoss) but it's too slick for the subject matter, and at barely 90 minutes, you'll still figure out exactly where it's going too soon into the piece.

This is one of the most boring movies I have ever seen. One of the problems was that all the subtitles were white type over white backgrounds. The other was that it moved so slowly that I almost fell asleep.

a tale of marriage, adversity, betrayal, greed, forgiveness and revelation in the context of a scarred holocaust concentration camp survivor who has to face with the dread that the person she was living for was not who she thought she knew, and as she faces the continual task of pretending to be her former self, she realizes who she wants to, and has to, be.

Fascinating top to bottom. A remarkable idea played out to perfection, with a score heavily featuring the music of the 20th Century's most diverse, evocative composer, Kurt Weill. A reminder of the true and profound harm the Nazis reaped upon not only Jews, upon their own nation as well, boiled down to intimate, personal story-telling that cannot help but move an audience.
A WWII era Vertigo that Hitchcock himself would approve.

Petzold, apesar de alguma reitere��o narrativa, filma soberbamente esta inquietante historia sobre dois seres humanos em perp�tua reconstru��o f�sica e mental. H� uma semelhan�a �bvia na reconstru��o com "Vertigo" de Hitchcock e ao fundo um rigoroso discurso com a frieza expositiva digna de Fritz Lang.

A very moving story of a woman who has been betrayed to the Nazis and returns to her home town to reconcile with her husband despite having a new face. The final scene remains long after the film has ended.
'Vertigo' set right after the Holocaust.

An intriguing story but contrived and it's difficult to suspend belief. It's quite slow but pretty engaging and the twist at the end is very satisfying. Nina Hoss is excellent as Nelly, the concentration-camp survivor. The best way to understand this movie is, according to some, not to take it literally. That may help to overlook the manufactured plot line. Some have suggested that it is an allegory - I'll leave viewers to decide that for themselves. Very atmospheric and explores some complex themes. A fresh take on post-Holocaust survival.

After their concentration camp is liberated following World War II, Nelly, a former cabaret singer, and her friend Lene return to Berlin. Nelly has plastic surgery to reconstruct her face, which was badly disfigured by a bullet. Though she's still beautiful, the surgery changes her appearance so she's no longer recognizable.Nelly and Lene rent an apartment. Since all of her relatives were killed in the war, Nelly stands to inherit a large sum of money which the two women will use to immigrate to Palestine. In the meantime, Nelly tracks down her husband Johnny, despite Lene's suspicions that he was the one who outed her in to the Nazis.Johnny doesn't recognize Nelly, nor does she identify herself. Instead, noting that she bears a striking resemblance to his dead wife, he hatches a plan to hide her away in his basement apartment until he can teach her enough to convincingly impersonate Nelly so he can collect her inheritance. Nelly willingly goes along with this scheme and is an incredibly quick study. As well she should be, given that she's learning to impersonate herself. One might think Johnny would become suspicious when a woman who looks so much like his wife displays such an uncanny ability to forge her handwriting, but no one in this movie is particularly insightful.If I had to pick one word to describe this film, it would be "implausible". As one who has a difficult time suspending disbelief, this was a toughie for me. There's mood and suspense and good acting but by the time I'd finish rationalizing one improbable plot twist, the story would present me with another. I saw a quote from director Christian Petzold in response to one apparently critical interviewer that "people who ask those questions don't like movies". Not true, Christian, not true. We like documentaries. And slice-of-life movies. And movies that aren't so damn plotty. And despite its numerous contrivances, I even liked your movie. Didn't love it. But appreciated it for what it is.Well-acted, suspenseful, and yes, implausible.
Powerful, brilliant.
Bets movie I have seen in 2015, it was really well acted and had a great story 5/5

The plot is difficult to believe....a spouse would recognize the voice, the walk, the mannerisms....and the film goes to great lengths showing other unique similarities. And the end would have been improved has she used her gift upon him.

You would expect a less shallow scenario and performances to tell such a story. In this game of treachery and appearances, no one is really convincing nor wholly committed in their part. Only the ending shows some sense and reason.
A most incredible and sad movie!

It has been a week or so since I saw this film. It is puzzling that I am still wonder about the ambiguity of the piece. It is the story of a young woman, Nelly, disfigured in the Holocaust. She survives and is rescued by a friend, Lene, who worships who she once was before. They go back after Nelly's plastic surgery to acquire Nelly's inheritance. Yet when Nelly goes back, her husband does not recognize her. She does not mind. She tries to attain her old identity as he has hired her as her own double to get the money himself. This is a haunting story...and you are never certain as to what it is really happening. This is perhaps more an examination of reclamation of Holocaust survivors identities and also the attempted escape of those culpable in the imprisonment of the many Jews. Barbara Hoss as Nelly and Ronald Zehrfeld as her husband who perhaps sent her to the camps. Mr. Pentzhold the director purposely creates a Hitchcock quality because we are never certain ourselves if Nelly is who she says. Or if her husband really did place her in the camp. The mystery comes to dramatic haunting climax. Excellent filmmaking and perhaps difficult for those who just want a plot that spells everything. Intriguing!
Expertly written and directed by Christian Petzold with powerhouse performances by Nina Hoss and Ronald Zehrfeld, "Phoenix", stands as a stunning accomplishment.
what a powerful film. what an ending!
excellent. the subtitles do not take away from this film. Wonderful acting and suspenseful.

It is a shame that most moviegoers will not see this film because it is one of the best films of 2015 and the best acting by either male or female so far this year. Nina Hoss is terrific in this and in the two that I have had the pleasure to watch her in (Barbara and A Most Wanted Man). An interesting story about an interesting woman during post war Berlin. (9-27-15)

So few movies have a slow-burning plot these days...and one where the audience starts out knowing nothing about the characters and then learns about them in bits-and-pieces is even more rare. I was completely captivated by Nelly for the entire film. The ending moments--when the audience fully understands Nelly and her relationships--is truly breathtaking.

I had to see it twice in one week because I could not stop thinking about it & had to make sure my daughter saw it. We loved Nina in A Woman in Berlin & she is at the top of everything in this film - so is Ronald! One of the best movies I've seen this year & there have been some good ones. I can usually predict a movie but this one held me until the last second & I watched my daughter react to it the same way. There are so many films on this subject but this approach was fresh & clean & well acted & so well filmed with lighting & mood & dark/light - LOVED IT & could see it again & again. Sometimes the second time you see a film it loses a lot because the element of surprise is gone but I enjoyed Phoenix as much or more the second time & caught things I didn't know I missed! Thank You Christian Petzhold!!!!!!!
film noir like and shot a little like 40s 50s movie on purpose. well-written plot and a great build-up to climax
The film was completely implausible. Comparisons with Hitchcock are overstated.

Beautiful, and incredibly moving, in spite of some plot holes and heavy-handed symbolism at the beginning. For me, one of the most intriguing parts of this story was the imperfect love of the husband, which was treated masterfully.

Wonderfully acted and a great story, see it now before the inevitable remake. A woman badly burnt at a concentration camp returns with a new face and sets about getting her husband back with sad consequences

Wow. Wow wow. This was super great. I was a little worried at first because I'd heard amazing things and from the first 45 minutes or so I was enjoying it but not invested to the point of real emotion. It was a movie I appreciated, but it's just not the kind of movie that I really cry at or truly love. As good as a prestige historical drama like this is, I'm probably never going to adore it as much as a progressive comedy like The Overnight or even just a clever constant-laughs comedy like Trainwreck. That's still true - in my rankings, this was just below Trainwreck - but in terms of genuine emotion, it hit me harder.I'm not really sure where to start. I guess I'll start by talking about the flaws, which are very few. It was a little bit of a stretch how Lene waited so long to tell Nelly about the fact that Johnny divorced her the day before she was arrested; it is a bit contrived how that only comes up after Lene kills herself. Frankly, Lene didn't really need to kill herself for the story, especially because the movie didn't really focus on her depression or anything.Most of these flaws don't matter much, though, because they're in service of something much greater. Nelly having the revelation of Johnny's betrayal late in the movie might be contrived, but it is that way for a reason for the climax to hit the way it does. Besides, it never really feels like the whole movie is wheel-spinning, even if it is delaying a lot of inevitable confrontations. And even Lene's suicide, while not exactly telegraphed, is important to making Nelly and Johnny feel truly isolated at the end, to making them feel like the only characters in the whole movie and the only people in the whole world.Every scene crackles with meaning. There are so many thematically dense scenes, like when Nelly comes out in the dress with her newly dyed hair and asks, "Do you recognize me?" At so many points in the movie, especially that scene, you can see Johnny's denial preventing him from truly coming to terms with the fact that this really is Nelly. Even from the beginning, he probably knows, somewhere deep down. He turns when she yells "Johnny," and something about her immediately makes him recognize her as someone who could 'play' his wife.One of my favorite things about the movie is how three-dimensional everyone is. In some soap opera melodrama, Johnny would be a cartoony asshole, greedily plotting to steal Nelly's money. I mean, that is SORT OF what he's doing, but it's clear that he has some genuine love for her, and that he has a lot of guilt for what he did, like any real human. If he didn't, the final scene wouldn't hit as hard as it does.But, yeah, that final scene. Even if I hadn't liked the rest of the movie, that final scene would've been memorable. It's the best closing scene since Whiplash last year, and funnily enough, they both involve an intense musical sequence. The whole length of the scene, I was staring, wide-eyed. The film juggles these two distinct tones marvelously: quiet tragedy and thriller-like intensity. Most of the movie isn't tense in the way that a thriller is; even in a movie like Whiplash, when actual murder is never the threat, it'd still make a kind of sense to call it a thriller, but Phoenix is a drama. But it's great the way Petzold integrates these elements of extraordinary tension into the story. The scene when Nelly obediently follows the script and embraces Johnny at the train station, I was really afraid of what she was going to do. Was she going to just shoot him right there? Was she going to scream, or punch him? But no, she follows the script, waiting for an even more impactful moment to reveal the truth.Overall, Phoenix is a dark and tragic tale of a betrayal and a woman who just wants to believe things can go back to the way they were before the Holocaust. It's not one of my top three favorite movies of the year, but it has by far the best last scene of the year, filled with sadness and intensity.
One of the best films I have ever seen. And I have seen a hell of a lot of films.
So much potential... so much to explore... So little depth.
If Hitchcock were alive and filmed in German, he'd have made Phoenix. An excellent, slow burn of a movie with a great ending.

The German post-World War II drama "Phoenix" (PG-13, 1:38) has a great mix of influences behind it. The title, of course, refers to the mythological bird that is reborn when it rises from the ashes of its former self. This film's story is loosely based on French writer Hubert Monteilhet's novel "Le Retour des cendres", which also inspired the 1965 British film "Return from the Ashes". This 2015 version makes changes to the plot and sets the story in Germany. It's also influenced by other films, including Hitchcock's classic, "Vertigo". Underlying all of this is the oft-repeated real-life drama of concentration camp survivors restarting their lives following unspeakable personal and family tragedies. This film takes that situation and tells a fictional story of one such woman whose return from the camps is even more complicated than most. It's disappointing that this movie isn't as interesting as its impressive pedigree.As "Phoenix" begins, Nelly Lenz (Nina Hoss) is being driven by her friend Lene (Nina Kunzendorf) back to Germany after being liberated from the infamous concentration camp at Auschwitz. Nelly had been left for dead after being shot in the face, a situation that requires her to have plastic surgery. Although the doctor isn't able to make her look exactly like she did before, Nelly ends up with a face that many women would appreciate having. As Nelly heals, she and Lene share an apartment and talk of joining other Jews in Palestine. Nelly's entire family died during the war, leaving her with an inheritance that she could use to relocate. In Palestine, Nelly and Lene could restart their lives, feel more secure and help to build a new Jewish state in the Middle East... but Nelly has something else that she needs to do first.Nelly was married at the time that she was arrested and sent to the camps. Lene believes that Nelly's husband, Johnny (Ronald Zehrfeld), betrayed Nelly to the Nazis, but Nelly isn't so sure. She searches Berlin until she finds Johnny, but thinks Nelly is dead and doesn't recognize her. He does, however, feel that she looks enough like his wife that he asks her to help him with a plan to get Nelly's inheritance for himself. Nelly conceals her true identity and goes along with Johnny as he thinks he's remaking some random woman into someone whom he can pass off as Nelly. She takes advantage of the situation to try and find out whether Johnny did turn her in, or if they might get back together and resume their lives."Phoenix" shows us little seen and increasingly forgotten places and situations, using them as a backdrop for an intriguing mystery. Post-war Berlin is seen as a place of bombed-out buildings and people struggling to put their lives back together and learn how to relate to each other again. Allied troops are on hand to keep order and transition the country back to a peaceful existence, but the return of peace is only the beginning. It takes time to heal war's wounds, in all their forms. Nelly is virtually unrecognizable, not just because of the surgical reconstruction of her face, but also due to the obvious toll that the war and the abuse she suffered in the camps has taken on her body and mind. Symbolic of so many who survived the war, Nelly walks differently, talks differently and seems to have lost any pleasure that she once had in living. Nina Hoss' performance is raw and real, but the others lack energy. The script gives us one-note characters with no background and, except for Hoss, the actors play down to that script and to the uninspired direction of Christian Petzold, who also served as co-writer. And the film's minimalist score doesn't help. The ending comes in one pseudo-dramatic moment, but it depends too much on the actors and not enough on narrative strength. Audience members are fairly likely to end this film with the same look on their faces as the actors in the last scene - with both groups wondering what they just saw and what happens next. It's a shame that such a great story couldn't have made for a better movie. "B"
Arty movie which will bore you to tears. Went after reading so many positive reviews here. Premise doesn't begin to fly. Depiction not worthy of a Hallmark TV movie.

spellbinding is a good term for this movie. I was half in a trance state by Nina Hoss's impeccable acting skills. She portrayed each powerful state of mind and emotion flawlessly. Don't miss it, it is subtitled but that was somehow not distracting at all.

Phoenix: Ziemlich gro�es Kino!Phoenix is a simple film with complicated themes of identity, survival, and loss. It is not your normal post WWII film, nor is it your typical concentration camp survivor story. The main character, Nelly, was in a camp and her trauma is reflected in the desperation of a divided Berlin. Her interactions with others are clearly influenced by her time in the camps, and Nina Hoss wonderfully portrays the protagonist. Unfortunately, the actor who plays the lead male, Johnny (Ronald Zehrfeld) is relatively ineffective compared to the stunning Hoss. I am not sure whether is is the script or the acting, but he clearly isn't up to her level. Nelly's best friend, Lena, is performed with skill by Nina Kunzendorf. While not as remarkable as Hoss, she holds her own in their scenes together. The look of the film is lovely, but it is clearly made on a budget. The music is appropriate for the mood and the era, though a couple of times too loud and overly dramatic. The pace is deliberate and effective. It is a good film that offers us no answers to the questions it poses: how do we survive after everything is taken away, how do we return to a life that no longer exists, whom do we trust now when many of our old friends were Nazi or collaborators during the war, how do we react to someone who returns who we thought was daed, and where do we go when nothing is left of our former life. In the film, like life, there are no easy answers. That only strengthens the film's appeal. Rating: Pay full price. I don't want to say to much for fear of giving too much away. The film, while not shocking, is not predicable. ??Peace, ?Tex Shelters
Great movie, well written well cast well acted. Nina Hoss is a great actress.
....slow.......but with an unusual story that echoes some plot lines of Vertigo

Emotionally devastating. This post-Holocaust German film defies categorization. Set in ravaged postwar Berlin, Nelly (played immaculately by Nina Hoss), a Jewish singer, returns as a facially disfigured concentration camp survivor, searches for her husband, Johnny (Ronald Zehrfeld), a piano player, who is suspected of betraying her to the Nazis. Nina Kunzendorf is empathic as Nelly's candid, loyal friend with no illusions about the events that transpired. After undergoing reconstructive surgery, Nelly finds Johnny working in a nightclub, but he doesn't recognize her. Nelly assumes the identity of a doppelganger, at her husband's request, to bequeath her inheritance to him and split the sum. This seemingly preposterous conceit never feels contrived under the deliberately assured direction of Christian Petzold. It plays as a sophisticated mystery with the style of a noir. The exquisite cinematography by Hans Fromm features dark shadows and symbolic framing. Nelly's transformation into her former self suggests "Vertigo" in reverse. In its execution, the haunting, ambiguous ending is perfection. Petzold examines the complex psychological state of postwar Germany suffering with identity, deception, denial, and guilt. This is a rare contemporary movie that assumes the audience's intelligence. It makes you conscious of how simplistic and manipulative other movies on this subject are. A lyrical song titled "Speak Low" is played at crucial moments to lingering effect. Music is by Kurt Weill. Co-written by Petzold and Harun Farocki, loosely based on the novel "Return from the Ashes" by Hubert Monteilhet, which was filmed before as a British film in 1965.

Christian Petzold, the director, has managed to take a somewhat novel concept and essentially squander it, as well as my time, on trying to impress his audience with a seemingly calculated "ironic" scene at the films end. The story trots lamely along carrying a burden what seems to be obvious stupidity and questionable motives on the part of the would be widower husband and his survivor wife, Nelle. Is he so stupid that he can't recognize wife who has had partially reconstructive surgery and is the wife so stupid that she can't give up on the man who may have betrayed her out of cowardice; these are some of the questions that leave the viewer confused and probably so because Petzod just can't wait to get to the end to make what he has presumably calculated to be a profound irony. The actors are also somewhat wooden in their performances and provide no insight into their psychological motivations for their behavior which again leaves the audience wondering. Nelle's friend, Lene, provides some modicum of reasonableness in the first half of the film but commits suicide nonetheless; you have to wonder if it was out of depression, which wasn't convincing, or more sardonically was it just wanting get out of this film and move on and find better director. Other reviewers have mentioned a Hitchcockian resemblance which leaves me totally baffled because I saw nothing suspenseful in the film and nothing thematically to remind me of Hitchcock's films.

Best Film of 2015! This is a difficult story and a foreign language film, so I doubt the Academy will give it its due, but wow! is this amazing. The acting is subtle, dark and quiet, echoing the deep seated pain of the characters involved. Cinematography is rich with grit and torn apart by war; every angle is off and just can't be made right (as it had to feel in post war Poland). The music is the most brilliant aspect, taking a single Kurt Weill song, Sing Low, and weaving it throughout in a haunting memory of pasts we can't get back. There is nothing about this film which doesn't perfectly fit the story. It is tough, dark and desperately needs to be seen. Love has many stories, and war many victims--there are things that keep us alive and deaths we never overcome.
It's a bit uneven, but the melancholic shade that coats this film pays off in a big way during the final scene.
This is the type of movie where you leave the theater and you have to just sit down and reflect on it for a moment.

Bizarre and strange film in which a Jewish woman survives the concentration camp and valiantly tries to find her German husband. When she finds him she recognizes him but he does not recognize her, due to two reasons. First, because of excessive guilt due to him telling the Nazis where she was hiding, and because her face has been disfigured due to being tortured in the camp. She pretends to be someone else hoping for the day he can recognize her. Meanwhile, he hatches a plan to find someone to impersonate his "deceased" wife in order to collect insurance and guess who he chooses !
story makes you think , feel and wonder on many levels. i highly urge it be seen.,,,

In a word: disappointing. After reading reviews comparing this film to a modern day Vertigo, I expected the cinematic experience to be rife with twists and turns, jaw-dropping revelations, and intrigue. Instead I spent an hour and a half watching a woman who somehow was strong enough to survive the Holocaust but not strong enough to leave her husband who was the cause of her arrest in the first place. Even when it was revealed to her husband her true identity she takes no action: there is no resolve or any indication of a character arc for Nina. We are only left to decide for ourselves what is to happen of this feeble woman who chose her abusive husband over her friends that were trying to provide her with an actual shot of a happy life. The only thing more unsatisfying about the main character being unable to fend for herself is that I spent 90 whole minutes watching absolutely nothing happen. This film seems to have an intriguing premise, but does not reach it's full potential.

I?m still smiling hours after seeing Phoenix just to have watched a movie so full of meaning. It?s far from the mind sweeping stories that fill Netflix. This movie does require you to have the patience to watch it slowly and quietly unfold, but if you give it that, it pays out in rich symbolism and brilliant acting. It?s like a fine artisan chocolate. Time-consumingly made layers of delicately crafted delights that melt so sweetly you need a moment of silence to just sit and appreciate the gift you were given.

Imagina ver tu rostro reflejado en el espejo y no reconocerlo. Una superviviente de Auschwitz, con un rostro nuevo e irreconocible, vuelve a Berl�n para buscar a su amado esposo, quien la cree muerta. "Un ave que resurge de sus cenizas para darse cuenta de que el motivo por el que lo estaba haciendo era errado." A pesar de su interesante premisa, la cinta tropieza constantemente por la verosimilitud de su gui�n. Sin embargo, vale la pena verla por su planteamiento, su delicada sobriedad y por tener uno de los mejores finales de este a�o.

Character study about forlorn love set against the backdrop of post-WW II Germany succeeds. The protagonist was arrested by the Nazis inlat 1944 and interned, and ultimately shot in the face. She returns to her husband's life unrecognized by him, and discovers the truth, which unbinds her from her love for him. Most of us have been in pathetic love with an unworthy person so this one will resonate in a big way.
You could have heard a pin drop in the theatre during this amazing performance by Nina Hoss.
superb twists and turns throughout... and what a finale!
Riveting, gut wrenching, and shattering...one of the best foreign film movies I've seen within memory. It's playing here at the Laemmle in Claremont through Wednesday.

The greatest elation I had was in walking out on this self-absorbed, unbelievably lazy, and overly drawn out piece of tripe. I can't believe the critics who are hailing it to the heavens actually saw the same movie, or perhaps saw it at all!

After all the summer crap, I thought that, with all the positive reviews, I was finally going to see a good film. WRONG! Badly written, poorly directed (even the Times agrees). This film is boring, terrible and . . . in a word . . . SUCKS! Money back, please.
That's was very Classic story book Never made?!!!
It's a fine film: very well directed, unusual and touching story and outstanding performances by actors. One of the best film to come out of Germany in years.
Fascinating, well crafted, well acted film. Was her friend interested in her as a lesbian and killed herself when she realized Nelly was still in love with Johnny?
Outstanding movie with a perfect Hitchcock ending. Excellent cast - I cannot think of a single way it could have been improved.
Garbage. It takes him the entire movie to know that the woman he is passing off as his wife is actually his wife???
Absolutely marvelous!
Bravo! The most perceptive, moving films about the Nazi period and Germanyin war & after have been made by Germans themselves!
Did not blow me away as I was watching it, but it has stuck with me overnight and I find myself thinking about it in many new ways the morning after. An interesting and very well made film.
Cant believe I went to this. Anytime I see the critics love a show I should run.
This is perhaps the S-L-O-W-E-S-T film I have ever seen with a tawdry macguffin of an ending. Yuck.
NZIFF #6: This masterful blend of mystery, noir, WWII drama, Hitchcockian(?) suspense and obsessions, is a slow-burning masterpiece with a fucking killer final scene.

A reworking of "Vertigo" set in the rubble post-World War II, when Europe and its various countries weren't too sure of their identities any more. Nelly has survived the concentration camps, but needed some plastic surgery; when she returns to the husband who divorced and betrayed her, he thinks she's a stranger he can use to get at her inheritance. Nina Hoss is resourceful enough as an actress that you go with her in the charade, wondering how far she'll take the role playing "herself," but a nagging sense of impatience is hard to dismiss at times, and though the socko climax--set to Weill's song "Speak Low"--has a punch, after that the movie more or less shrugs. It's been made with talent and craft, but it holds its cards a little too closely to the vest.
An extra dose of "suspension of disbelief" got me through to a very impressive and inspiring ending.
As a singer, I relating in a very emotional way to the final scene; sadly moving.
Oh Foreign Films, I have missed you. Mostly in German, slow and artistic, with an ending to die for. Loved.
An amazing film on many levels, i romantic, anti-romantic (if there is such a term) cruel, forgiving... you leave exhausted from feellng. A gem of a flick.

Slow, poorly scripted story based on an absurd premise. Worst movie I've seen in years! A man can't recognize his own wife, but believes, with a little coaching, she can successfuly impersonate herself with her friends...a twelve year old could write a better story. The purported plastic surgery may account for actress Nina Hoss's blank face throughout.

While it can be a tense and involving watch, Phoenix is, beneath the craft, a short film expanded into ninety-plus minutes. That is, at thirty minutes we'd have the effect as we have at ninety.  The film first establishes its premise, which is intriguing and deep: a woman, coming out of a Nazi concentration camp, has a face transplant due to injury. She is unrecognizable to her husband, but similar enough that, when the two reunite, he asks her to imitate his old wife (actually the protagonist) in order to inherit her property. Her motivation in not telling him who she really is is not always clear, but is justified enough by her apparent want to be identified without having to explain herself. The allegorical connection to history this plot establishes the viewer can fairly easily deduce.  What follows is, save for the provocative last scene, repetition and insistence on drawling out this plot without deepening it or taking it to new heights. So, for example, there is a sequence of events where she attempts to prove her identity to her husband by first imitating her signature and then wearing her old shoes, which fit perfectly. Each of these events, which at the film's slow pace stretch about five minutes each, say the same thing. Each deems the other unnecessary since both are to the same effect. This goes on and on, where the viewer is invested solely for the moment when he may finally recognize her. Repetitive also are the glances and gazes between the the protagonist and her husband. The acting in combination with the editing leads to brilliant minimal drama at times, but when we're seeing the same silent facial acting towards the end of the film that we also saw in the beginning attempting to create the same effect, well, it makes you question the film's integrity.  I think the film's integrity is this: It plays it safe. It establishes an interesting metaphor, and doesn't roll with it as much as it could have. It shrinks the surrounding historical events into the evocative faces of its two leads. Artful sure, but compelling only for a while. And the bottom line is that it didn't move me. The film wanted to be devastating but I wasn't devastated. The film wanted to be subtly heart-wrenching but my heart wasn't wrenched. I felt at the end, "Alright, that was it. There it was." In other words I didn't feel much besides the mild and consistent tension throughout. There's only so much you can accomplish in a film with these parameters. This review is not primarily negative because the film was bad but because the critic consensus is overwhelmingly positive. An excellent short film, but only a good film.

Phoenix is well done in many departments, but is flawed in its tradeoff of developing its allegory for a surface-level story that is admittedly engaging.The film's first 20-30 minutes are slow paced, but laced with allegory and metaphors for the Jews' post-holocaust struggle for getting back their former selves. I thought Nelly's physical unrecognizeableness (I know it's not a word) was a good way to represent her inner loss of identity.From start to finish, the film impresses technically with perfectly decayed walls in the art direction and finely crafted cinematography, particularly how it highlighted the Phoenix nightclub. Nelly wants to find her husband, but discovers not only that he does not recognize her (because she got face surgery from her face being holocausted), but thinks she's dead, and wants to use her to pretend to everyone else that she's Nelly to get some money. Nelly doesn't tell him it's really her; she wants him to find out himself. Suspending the disbelief that he would recognize her voice, body, or hands, it's a tense plot, with the question as to weather or not he will find out lingering over the film. However, once this plot point is established, the film stops developing its allegory altogether. Now it's just a movie about her and her husband, having lost the political context along the way.Not only does it lack political context, it lacks emotional context. The situation feels entirely Nelly's, and there wasn't anything I could latch onto as a person not having survived the holocaust and trying to rekindle with my husband who doesn't recognize me. The question as to weather or not she gets her identity back is not that engaging thematically either. If she does, then the movie states that Jews were able to get theirs back. If not, then they weren't. If in between, then it's just a question. Without developing the themes or allegory any further, the film dooms itself to being basic.This is not to say that it's a failure of a film. The acting by Nina Hoss is superb, looking into her husbands eyes, desperate for him to recognize her soul beneath her own. Ronald Zehrfeld is great as well, responding to these looks, curious with her uncanny resemblance, but still (somehow) ignorant to the truth. The facial exchanges between the two are pretty remarkable. Still, it's a bit strange how emotionally devastated Hoss is the entire movie in front of everyone she encounters and how none of them seem to notice or ask if she's okay. Petzold should have requested a bit more subtlety from his actress at times.It's also a fairly tense mystery, building on Nelly finding out things about her husband she'd never had known otherwise, forcing her to rethink her relationship. This develops the film thematically a bit because it shows that no matter the outcome, the couple's relationship may not be the same. The ending is a perfect climax to the story and a great combination of acting, direction, and editing. In the end though, the film relies heavily on allegory for its thematic heft, and then drops it, leaving me with no way to really connect the film to much at all. Strong performances and story kept me interested, but I don't see how the film is great.

so very interesting, intriguing, couldn't take my eyes off it. It was one of my favorites at the Toronto Film Festival last year and so I had to see it again yesterday. Second time around...just as good.

Good movie, very different story, unusual. Nina Ross did a superb job of making you feel her pain and strength as the story went along. Not quite what you expect, but very good after you realize what is happening!

+"They don't make them like the did in the old days, " is the cry of many senior film buffs, including me. In "Phoenix" the director, and co-writer with Harun Farocki, Christian Petzold certainly tries. With bits of Alfred Hitchcock's "Vertigo" here, Kander and Ebb's, with Fosse's, "Cabaret" there, this movie, as film noir, cries out for a Barbara Stanwyck or Lana Turner and to have been filmed in black and white.The story of a woman, Nelly, who had her face damaged by a gunshot wound in a German concentration camp has her face reconstructed after the war and goes looking for her husband Johnny. Upon finding him he doesn't recognize her and tries to get her involved with a get rich scheme by having her impersonate his late wife so he can get her inheritance that was left by her relatives who died in the war."As Time Goes By" is an important part of "Casablanca" as are "Again" in "Road House" and "Que Sera, Sera" in "The Man Who Knew Too Much" and this movie too has a song that becomes an important part of the story, by Kurt Weill and Ogden Nash, called "Speak Low" which is heard throughout the film and impacts the ending.Nina Hoss, as Nelly, may not have the sexuality of a Lana Turner, and is a beauty in her own right, but she is the equal of Barbara Stanwyck in the acting department. She can and does say a lot with a look, her eyes through bad or good and the way she holds herself. You watch her progression from a scared, downtrodden woman to the beautiful, confident woman she was before the war. Ronald Zehrfeld, as her husband Johnny, who thinks that she can pass for his wife that could help him put his scam over has doubts about who she really may be but not enough to stop him. Zehrfeld has a romantic innocence that makes him seem less the villain than he is.Another major, but undeveloped, role is Nina Kunzendorf as Lene, who does a lot for Nelly but their relationship isn't quite defined and is unceremoniously out of the film before the halfway mark.I was told by Allen that the film was an analogy of Germany after the war but I will admit it went right over my head! It might account for why I didn't like the film as much as I expected to but it did introduce me to Hoss, Zehrfeld and Petzold enough for me to want to see the previous films they have made together."Phoenix" is a German film with (some poor such as 'sit up' instead of 'sit down') subtitles running 98 minutes.

Director Christian Petzold and actress Nina Hoss have now brought us a string of accomplished films exploring Germany's past and present, culminating with the extraordinary BARBARA. What a disappoint it is to report on PHOENIX. A metaphorical conception of a concentration camp survivor given a new face (literally) only to come back to Berlin to follow her husband, the man that betrayed her. PHOENIX is worthy of Sirk or Fassbinder. Petzold's direction is without merit and he gives one of our best actresses nothing to do. A total misfire that I found downright dull.

Save your money. It's a stinker. Thin plot that goes no where sloppy acting and no tension. The Jewish take is worst of all in that the only sane Jew gives up on life for no reason at all. Totally out of character
A somber drama, that pays some assured homage to great German filmmakers such as Douglas Sirk, and Rainer Werner Fassbinder (yet still escapes the trappings of melodrama).
PROBABLY THE WORST MOVIE OF THE LAST 10 YEARS! so sad I had very high expectations
A little noir, a little Hitchcock, solid performances, a gut-punch last scene.
Suspenseful and depressing, as all post WWII films that deal with such subjects generally are.

Beware. Seeing a movie the day it's released can be risky. So it was with "Phoenix," the latest German language film from writer/director Christian Petzold. With a 98 score from Rottentomatoes I assumed I was in for a satisfying 98 minutes. Audiences willingly sit in a darkened room, watching representations of real life because, at the very least, they expect the story to be plausible. Judge for yourself. It is 1945, and Nelly (Nina Hoss) returns from Auschwitz with her face terribly disfigured. After reconstructive surgery she finds her husband Johnny (Ronald Zehrfeld), who fails to recognize her, even though she addresses him by his real, not assumed name. I feel stupid just outlining the "plot." Johnny asks Nelly to pose as his wife so they can claim her inheritance. She goes along, no doubt hoping he'll finally recognize her. Nelly's face may have changed, but her voice hasn't, nor have her hands or her handwriting. And that's with her clothes on.
I thought this to be a good old revenge movie but no, it is a war love story which starts well but looses steam by the middle entering into a melodrama territory.
Hoss still the boss.
Tom Castro+Emma Zunz
a true poetry. Reminds me of , and many other tales of Borges.

The thin story here feels a little stretched out but it is well told and executed. How you rate the film will depend on your tolerance on the underlying contrivance on which the narrative relies. You will either see it as a distracting irritant that will taint your enjoyment of the film or, if you are able to overlook that, you will find a thoughtful and interesting film which ends with a precision that epitomize German efficiency and succinctness. For me, the film starts slow and I was in the former camp until I was slowly and eventually won over. The power of a poignant and compelling ending can never be underestimated.
We saw it last night and are still talking about it this morning ! A thought provoking story of betrayal ? Excellent , go see

I saw this film at the Toronto Film Festival and thought it was the best of the many films I saw. The final scene took my breath away. I think it will be released in the US in July. I can't recommend it enough!
Strongly recommended.

Confrontational and painful this film explores post war germany and the repercussions of living in a fascist state. At first Nelly is trying to find herself after the concentration camp and her lose of self is reflected in her fellow jews desperate desire to believe in Israel but then she rises and she forces the ones left behind to look at what they have done. Breathtaking.

Dynamite movie! So non-Hollywood in a refreshing way. Nina Host plays her character brilliantly and shows the brokenness of a woman who survived th Holocaust, only to return to a husband who doesn't recognize her. The audience feels her pain together with her in such a moving way.
The film piece on the weak script and lack of pretense. A film sugar water and bland.

ALTAMENTE RECOMENDADA Una de las pel�culas que mejor calificaci�n ha recibido de parte de los cr�ticos y del p�blico es Phoenix (Ave F�nix), protagonizada por Nina Hoss en una de sus mejores performances - y tambi�n de las m�s exigentes -. Una historia postguerra, que cuenta el drama de una sobreviviente del holocausto jud�o que luego de someterse a una cirug�a reconstructiva trata de recuperar su vida pasada desde su nueva identidad. Desperada y ansiosa por reencontrar a su marido, har� todo lo que est� a su alcance para volver con �l, pero el encuentro ser� muy diferente a lo esperado. CRITICA 5 ESTRELLAS, P�BLICO 5 ESTRELLAS.

Nina Hoss gives a stellar performance here as concentration camp survivor Nelly in Christian Petzold's tense film that cleverly blurs the lines between suspense drama and modern noir. Going in search of her husband Johnny after undergoing facial reconstruction work, viewers are kept guessing as to whether he betrayed Nelly and what actions will be taken as a result, leading to an incredibly moving and satisfying conclusion.
Fantastic, noir-ish, best-of-fest film. I loved this one.

Nina Hoss, again (After Barbara and the bicycling around the windy coast line) a strong female who prevails and gets her revenge. I had hoped more of evil getting even in the end, but as it was..... it did the trick too. I did not cry, so something was missing, clearly.
Saw this at TIFF 2014. If you get a chance, see this one.
From the director of Barbara, another masterpiece.

Nina Hoss delivers perhaps the very best and most challenging performance of her career in this gripping film about what it is like to become a stranger to the person you love (and vice versa) - even though the suicide of a certain character comes up as quite unnecessary.

So this movie isn't out in the States yet, and I'm not sure when/if it will get an American release, but it is the best film I've seen in ages. If you get the chance, check it out! Especially if you're a German New Wave fan or any type of film scholar.
